awd_titl_txt: Protactinium and Niobium Measurements in Young Volcanic     Rocks by Thermal Ionization Mass Spectrometry
awd_abstract_narration: The primary goal of this project is to determine both the                       prevalence and magnitude of protactinium-uranium fractionation in               volcanic rocks, so that the igneous processes causing the                       fractionation can be identified and temporally constrained.  The                secondary goal is to produce, purify, and calibrate an isotope-                 dilution spike for Nb, and to develop the analytic methods to                   make isotope dilution thermal ionization mass spectrometry (ID-                 TIMS) measurements of Nb in geologic materials.  A third goal                   assumes that protactinium and niobium have chemical properties so               similar that Nb may be considered a stable analog of Pa.  This                  hypothesis will be tested by analyzing young volcanic rock                      samples for Nb as well as Pa, Th and U.
